terms.definition: The section of U.S. copyright law that outlines the fundamental exclusive rights belonging to a copyright owner.
The section of U.S. copyright law that specifies the types of monetary damages available for copyright infringement.
The section of U.S. copyright law that permits courts to award attorney's fees and costs to the winning party in a copyright lawsuit.
A formal legal letter demanding that an individual or entity immediately stop an allegedly illegal or infringing activity.
The unauthorized use or reproduction of a copyrighted work, violating the exclusive rights of the copyright owner.
The government agency responsible for registering copyrights and managing copyright records in the United States.
Financial compensation awarded to a plaintiff to cover the documented financial losses directly caused by an infringement.
The money paid to a lawyer for their legal services, which may be awarded to the winning party in a lawsuit.
A legal protection for original works of authorship that grants the creator exclusive rights to use and distribute their work.
An original creative work, such as a book, song, or image, that is legally protected by copyright.
Specific legal privileges granted to a copyright owner, allowing only them to perform certain actions with their work.
The act of showing a copyrighted work to the public, either directly or through technology, in a public setting.
In accordance with, or as authorized by, a specific law, rule, or agreement.
The legal relief or compensation available to a party whose rights have been violated, such as monetary damages or court orders.
The act of making copies of an original work, which is one of the exclusive rights of a copyright owner.
Predetermined monetary awards set by law that a copyright owner can choose instead of proving their specific financial losses from infringement.
The voluntary act of giving up a known legal right or claim.
